Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs and Co-PIs of grants supported through the NSF-NIH-ANR-BMBF-BSF Collaborative Research in Computational Neuroscience (CRCNS) program meet annually. This thirteenth meeting of CRCNS investigators brings together a broad spectrum of computational neuroscience researchers supported by the program, and includes poster presentations, talks, plenary lectures, and workshops.
The meeting is scheduled for June 14-16, 2017 and is hosted by Brown University. More information is available at http://crcns2017.brown.edu.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Collaborative Research in Computational NeuroScience (CRCNS) program supports collaborative activities that will advance the understanding of nervous system structure and function, mechanisms underlying nervous system disorders, and computational strategies used by the nervous system. It is joint program between the National Science Foundation (NSF), the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the German Federal Ministry of Education and Research (Bundesministerium für Bildung und Forschung, BMBF), the French National Research Agency (Agence Nationale de la Recherche, ANR), the United States-Israel Binational Science Foundation (BSF), and, beginning in 2018, Japan’s National Institute of Information and Communications Technology (NICT). The lead investigators of grants supported by the CRCNS program meet annually. This award helped support the thirteenth meeting of CRCNS investigators, bringing together a broad spectrum of computational neuroscience researchers supported by the program, and including poster presentations, talks, keynote lectures, and workshops. The 2017 meeting was held June 14-16 at Brown University and at the nearby Institute for Computational and Experimental Research in Mathematics (ICERM), in Providence, Rhode Island. There were roughly 200 attendees, with 30 research talks, including keynote talks by Dr. Matthew Botvinick (DeepMind and University College London) and Dr. Shin Ishii (Kyoto University), a poster session with over 50 posters, a panel discussion about undergraduate training in computational neuroscience, including ways to increase the representation of historically underrepresented groups, and a workshop at ICERM on Integrating Dynamics and Statistics in Neuroscience.
